title: RL34413
content: Only public safety officers or their eligible survivors can receive PSOB benefits. A public safety officer is defined as an individual serving a public agency in an official capacity as a law enforcement officer, firefighter, chaplain, or in certain FEMA-related roles during disasters or emergencies. The PSOB program provides a death benefit to eligible survivors of public safety officers who die as a direct result of a traumatic injury sustained in the line of duty or certain work-related heart attacks or strokes. The PSOB program provides a death benefit to eligible survivors of public safety officers who die in the line of duty from a heart attack, stroke, or vascular rupture during non-routine stressful physical activities. The death benefit is a one-time lump sum payment of $350,079, which is determined by the date of the officer's death. Survivors of public safety officers who died in the line of duty may receive a death benefit based on specific dates. The benefit amount is $350,079 and is paid upon approval of the claim. Survivors of public safety officers who died in the line of duty may receive a death benefit under the PSOB program. The benefit amount is $350,079 and is paid to eligible survivors in a specific order based on their relationship to the officer. The PSOB program provides a death benefit to survivors of public safety officers who died in the line of duty. If the officer has no designated beneficiary or life insurance policy, the benefit is distributed to surviving parents or adult, non-dependent children. Title XIII of P.L. 101-647 also includes a disability benefit for permanently and totally disabled officers. The disability benefit program provides a one-time lump sum payment of $350,079 to public safety officers permanently and totally disabled in the line of duty due to a catastrophic injury. Eligibility includes federal, state, and local law enforcement officers, firefighters, and rescue squad members injured on or after November 29, 1990. Employees of FEMA and state, local, and tribal emergency management agencies, as well as chaplains serving police or fire departments, are eligible for disability benefits under the PSOB program. Benefits will not be paid in cases of intentional misconduct, voluntary intoxication, gross negligence, or if the survivor's actions contributed to the injury. The PSOB Office determines eligibility for death or disability benefits for public safety officers based on various factors, with a presumption against survivor's actions contributing to the injury. The PSOEA program provides educational assistance to spouses and children of officers killed or disabled in the line of duty. The PSOEA program offers education benefits for spouses and children of deceased or disabled public safety officers, covering expenses like tuition, room and board, books, and fees. Spouses can receive benefits anytime, while children are eligible until age 27 unless there are exceptional circumstances. The assistance period can be extended for delays in benefit approval. The maximum education funding is 45 months for full-time education. The monthly benefit amount is $1,041 for full-time college attendance. Under the PSOEA program, families of public safety officers are covered for line-of-duty deaths and disabilities. Claimants can appeal denied claims within 33 days by requesting a determination from a hearing officer and submitting supporting evidence or legal arguments. The claimant can file supporting evidence or legal arguments with the request for a hearing officer determination. The hearing officer reviews the claim de novo and makes a determination. A claimant can request a hearing within 90 days of the claim being assigned to a hearing officer. The Director of BJA extends the filing deadline for a hearing where evidence is collected from the claimant and witnesses. The hearing officer may exclude evidence with low probative value. Witnesses are prevented from hearing each other's testimony. If a claim is denied, the claimant can appeal to the Director within 33 days. If not appealed, the hearing officer's determination is final. The claimant can appeal a denied claim to the Director within 33 days, and if denied again, can further appeal to the United States Court of Federal Claims. The Director's determination is the final agency decision.
